--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains762@...>
wrote:
>
> Tracey Annison wrote:
>
> > So I don't see how you can write a test class that has failing tests
> > that move over to passing tests as you write the code, (as I see TDD
> > asking for) when the thing you're testing doesn't exist yet. I guess
> > you could code in all the skeleton of the class, with the methods &
> > such (though this won't compile unless you really do return what you
> > say you will), then write the tests, then add the rest of the code.
> > But I don't see the great advantage of that, to be honest...
>
> I write the test, then use Eclipse to generate classes, interfaces and
> method stubs as I go. When the test compiles, I run it to watch it
fail.
> This way I know my test actually tests /something/. Only then do I
make
> it pass.
>
> When I do this, I get the opportunity to see my code in black and
white
> on the screen. I get to ask myself, "Is the design any good?" or more
> correctly, "Does the design suck in an obvious way?" I'm surprised how
> often it does. :) It's often not until I have to /use/ the API that I
> realize it sucks.
>
> So that's how I do it. I tried writing the skeleton code, then writing
> the test, but I found I couldn't easily enough track in my head the
code
> I needed for the test I wanted to write, so I decided to let the test
> pull the code out of me. It works for me.
>
> Take care.
> --
> J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger :: http://www.jbrains.ca
> Your guide to software craftsmanship
> JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
> 2005 Gordon Pask Award for contribution Agile Software Practice
>

Tracey --
Just want to add a tidbit of clarification to J.B.'s response (I may
stating the obvious, but nonetheless).

From the sounds of your initial post, it sounds that possibly you intend
to write many tests at once ["..code the skeleton..with the
methods..then write the tests.."].  There is a fundamental rule of TDD
to write one and only one failing test at a time and make that pass
before moving on to the next test.

This is very important because it will encourage you to constantly
refactor, enabling your brain to evolve a much cleaner overall design as
you go.  In addition, this tends to make the task of "getting the test
to compile" much less tedious, as you will need to add at the very most
only a single class and a single method.

Hope that helps.
   -- MB
